messages.content: Explain to me like I’m 5 the theory one can color in each map with 4 colors

Sure, here is a simple explanation of the four color theorem:

Imagine you have a map that has many countries, states or regions. The four color theorem says that you only need four colors to color in the map so that no two adjacent regions have the same color. 

For example, if you have a map of the United States, you can color each state one of four colors - red, blue, green or yellow - so that no two states that share a border have the same color. You don’t need more than four colors to do this.

This may seem obvious but it took mathematicians a long time to prove. The key idea is that no map, no matter how complicated, requires more than four colors. Any map, even a map with thousands of regions, can be colored with just four colors. 

So in short, the four color theorem means that any map can be colored in using only four crayons! No map is so complex that it needs more colors than that to properly color in neighboring regions.

Does that make sense? Let me know if you have any other questions!
OK now explain to me the mathematical proof (assume that I have a degree in cs)

Sure, here is a high-level overview of the mathematical proof for the four color theorem:

The first proof was proposed in 1976 by mathematicians Appel and Haken. They used a "computer-assisted" proof, which was controversial at the time. The basic idea of their proof is:

1. Show that there are only a finite number of possible maps on a sphere with a given number of regions. This is done by showing that for any map, there are only a finite number of ways to add an additional region while maintaining planarity. 

2. Use the computer to check each of these possible maps, and show they are all 4-colorable. This proves that any map on a sphere is 4-colorable.

3. Show that any planar map can be transformed into a map on a sphere by adding a new region that envelops the entire map. So if all maps on a sphere are 4-colorable, all planar maps must also be 4-colorable.

To check that each possible map is 4-colorable, they used a "discharging" algorithm. The idea is to give each region a "charge" of 4, then redistribute charges between neighboring regions according to a set of rules that ensure no region ends up with charge > 4. If the total charge is redistributed this way and remains >= 0 for all regions, the map must be 4-colorable.

The controversial part was the use of a computer to check so many possible maps. Mathematicians couldn't verify the proof manually. But since then, new proofs have been found that don't require a computer. The most well-known is the "ringing proof" from the 1990s which uses more advanced mathematics to prove the theorem.

That's the essence of the mathematical proof for the four color theorem. Let me know if you have any other questions!
